title: While I still loathe posting here...are the days of General Discussion numbered?
body:
I figured this would be the best place to post this question, since more Reds tend to check this particular area out.

But...pretty much what the title says. What are your plans for General Discussion as they stand right now? Are we going to see any improvements in the forum (avatars, post tracking, and the like)? Do I need to be worried about its closure, and if not, do I need to worry about it being abandoned by the developers?

I still hate it here. This layout still makes my eyes bleed. I will never post here on a regular basis. But as long as I can remain where I'm at now, I'm willing to begrudgingly tolerate this place.

replies.body:
I'd love to know more about what you don't like here. I think generally we'd like to get the boards to a place where the vast majority of players obviously prefer them to the forums, but we're really taking a "free market" approach to growth here. 

Even inside of Riot - we're asking people to try these out but not forcing anyone to do so. Some people love them, some hate them and in either case we're getting as much feedback as we can to improve the system here.

It's not likely that many feature improvements will be made to the forums. They're very expensive (on development time) to improve relative to the impact of the improvements. Something that takes a few hours to do here would take days or weeks over there. There will be times though when improving something here means it's a lot easier to improve something over there, so we'll absolutely do that. Finally replacing the question marks with summoner icons is a great example of that.

If you have time could you please get more specific about things that you like and don't like here? When you say "layout" do you mean how comments nest, the colors used, the markdown system, not having bumps, etc?

**tl;dr** We don't have hard-set plans to close General Discussion but that doesn't mean it won't ever happen. We are taking an "organic" approach to building following over here by trying to make this a great place for people to go.

The upvoting/downvoting system is still incredibly offputting to me. I recently went on the LoL reddit because I was bored and wanted to see if something interested me. Basically everything on the 'hot' tab was esports related, which is boring to me, so I clicked on one that said 'don't nerf twitch and lucian, buff other adcs.' What I saw was that everything that agreed with the premise of the thread (adcs are weak and they should be buffed instead of nerfed) was upvoted and easily visible, while everything that disagreed (lucian and twitch are too strong and need to be nerfed/adcs are fine) were downvoted to the bottom. This had nothing to do with the quality of the post, merely content. Hell, someone in the thread even posted 'and the adc circlejerk is in full swing.'

Like, apperantly you're fine with people just agreeing with each other because they already agreed with that point in the first place, but I don't see what the point of a 'discussion' is if the posts that people will see, the ones that are upvoted, are simply things like 'I agree, I got killed by an assassin last game and it sucked!' while things like 'I disagree, the primary problem with ADCs is their itemization, and buffing them without addressing that would lead to another S2, where ADCs ruled surpeme' get downvoted, based entirely upon the points they are trying to make.

We're certainly planning on making ways for you to opt-out of viewing types of content. I think we can do a lot of stuff to make content more relevant to you over time so I'd encourage you to check back every now and then.

Would be curious to see if you feel the same "no discussion" in this post as a comparable

http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/site-feedback/7qJ4ZGIk-weve-begun-247-moderation-hooray

The format shouldn't necessarily lead to a lack of discussion, but can depending on who you give it to and how it's moderated.

Are you asking if I feel that there's a lack of discussion in that thread? Or are you trying to use it an as example of something that has discussion? 

Either way it's not really comparable, because Tamat is a red, who is guaranteed to has his replies seen because of the redtracker and the fact that his replies don't get their positioning changed because of downvotes. Notice how some of his comments are as low as -12. Hell, you can't compare reds to normal posters, because reds are more polarizing. They tend to get a bunch of upvotes by simply saying hi, or a bunch of downvotes just because they did their job.

I'd have no problems with this system if it weren't for the fact that people are idiots and would screw it up. I'd be fine if people downvoted me for not liking how I said something, but I don't want to get downvoted just because I disagreed with them.

A downvote is a single data point - albeit a really visible one, but one thing that we're hoping to be able to accomplish here is a much greater level of individual relevance - even if it's going to be awhile before we can tackle some of those problems.

A great example could be something like giving preference to posts that were made by people in your social circle, or people who you choose to follow. We can know that you prefer seeing only certain types of discussions because you can opt in/out of different groups. 

> his replies don't get their positioning changed because of downvotes

This isn't true actually! Right now red posts don't get any special treatment regarding positioning.

> I'd have no problems with this system if it weren't for the fact that people are idiots and would screw it up. I'd be fine if people downvoted me for not liking how I said something, but I don't want to get downvoted just because I disagreed with them. 

Are there particular discussions that you really enjoy on the forums? We love to see examples of those to see if we can do things to make sure that the quality of discussion can be preserved.

> This isn't true actually! Right now red posts don't get any special treatment regarding positioning.

Really? I've seen a lot of negative 10+ red posts that were far higher than I expected them to before that downvote count, but maybe I just don't understand how this system works.

> Are there particular discussions that you really enjoy on the forums? We love to see examples of those to see if we can do things to make sure that the quality of discussion can be preserved.

Not to toot my own horn, but [these](http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/miscellaneous/nOeF6weR-ironstylus-regarding-the-community-beta) [two](http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/miscellaneous/LrXeIh1H-sion-relaunch-thread) threads were very focused and driven, keeping almost entirely on top, and allowed for good discussion. In my opinion, this is because IronStylus stayed with the discussion and forced it to remain on track, while the OP was incredibly focused and specifically asked people for their opinions. Generally speaking, I'm fairly certain this only worked because there was a red there from the very beginning, but if you can make this work for user-moderated discussions, go ahead.

Position is determined by the entire tree, not just the post. So the reply to the -10 could be +100 and the combined tree will be hire than its peers.

>Not to toot my own horn, but these two threads were very focused and driven, keeping almost entirely on top, and allowed for good discussion. In my opinion, this is because IronStylus stayed with the discussion and forced it to remain on track, while the OP was incredibly focused and specifically asked people for their opinions. Generally speaking, I'm fairly certain this only worked because there was a red there from the very beginning, but if you can make this work for user-moderated discussions, go ahead.

I actually meant on the other forums versus over here, but this is helpful too

> Position is determined by the entire tree, not just the post. So the reply to the -10 could be +100 and the combined tree will be hire than its peers.
> 

This also works both ways though don't forget.

The problem I have is that in a heated discussion, where emotions are high you need to be able to visibly see both sides of the conversation even when its just a few people vs many.

What often happens is that a Mob Mentality is created around particularly sensitive subjects.  At that point, any post that isn't in agreement with the Mob is downvoted to obscurity leaving only negative posts that encourage each other to be negative.  This only makes the Mob bigger and skews the perspective of everyone reading it.  It also means that everyone in the Mob feels even more justified in their beliefs.

For examples of this look at the "Rengar Rework Strikes Back" thread, where large portions of the thread become aggressive tantrums directed at Scruffy with huge upvotes on all negative posts and massive downvotes on all positive posts or even Scruffy's own posts.


You said above that the position of a post is determined by the tree not the post itself, as though this will combat it somewhat.  But honestly I can only see this making the problem worse once people understand how it works.  What you're saying is, if I don't like someones post, I can deliberately make a ton of replies to that post saying something like "DOWNVOTE ME HERP DERP!" and cause the tree to receive a huge number of downvotes from my replies.

In the same way a downvoted thread "may" be resurrected by people upvoting the replies (which is more unlikely), an upvoted thread can be deliberately tanked by creating downvoted replies (far more likely).  It also means that for every reply made, a single person has an additional point of control over that tree's position.

As long as its possible to control the position of a post, in any way, there will be people, or more likely large groups of people, who will abuse that system in order to dictate the conversation.  The only reason we don't see that happening here at present is that those same people are too attached to GD, or otherwise haven't worked out how to do it yet...

> I actually meant on the other forums versus over here, but this is helpful too

Ah, than I'd say the Rengar and Yorick rework threads. When the discussion changed, it was easy to tell when one kit was scrapped and another began, and it allowed for an easy measuring of the community's mood regarding the changes.

I think the most important distinction between what this should be and Reddit is that Reddit is a news site, while this is (or should be) a discussion site. The way the Reddit karma system works, no post however popular will last more than a few days. Some of the best GD threads, in contrast, have been quite long-running.

I would make two specific suggestions:

* Not all karma should decay. Instead, perhaps give posts both base karma (based on posts and votes) and "novelty karma" (perhaps based on a newness factor multiplied by posts/votes). Let the novelty karma fall off Reddit-style, but leave base karma alone. Alternately, base karma should only decay when people stop posting in the thread.

* Both posts and votes should be factored into visibility. Perhaps set a limit, such as only counting the first post by each user.

Pendragon, it isn't so hard to wrap ones head around. Your customers are being very direct with you

Why is it so complicated to understand that a lot of the community simply does not like the Reddit upvote or downvote system that leads to having upvoted threads be more visible? Just remove that system altogether and do something different with the up votes themselves. You can have the upvote counter visible which will attract people to the thread but it's visibility depends on how up to date the post is, like in the old forums. You can have a trending section for the community beta which can help people quickly access high upvote threads w/o them having to crowd out newer posts or constructively controversial ones which may have a net amount closer to zero upvotes because of their nature (say a constructive discussion on balance). Along with that you can implement what you said about following certain Community members if one likes their posts.

Reddit's upvote system opens the door to superficial discussion and the risk of having a bunch of "circlejerk" threads that don't ammount to anything positive and crowd out better threads. If your mods really want to clean out toxic threads (porn, flaming other players, etc.) you can implement this into your mod upgrading for the forums ahead of time I'm sure. 

Doing this people can pick and choose what kinds of threads they like but it gives equal visibility to all threads made while quickly rooting out the bad ones with mid presence. 

This is just some ideas I have but I hope you consider it in upgrading the forums. I see a lot of potential for the Community Beta so far.

While the format isn't really the same as the forums and there are issues with this style of board that still need worked out, I think that this community is a lot easier to keep up with red posts in. The Red Tracker works amazingly, allowing you to see each post by a Rioter as they appear. The Rioter Rundown is also really useful in large threads, since it can be difficult to sift through comments and just read all the Riot replies sometimes.

Yeah, there are some other features that I'd personally like to see added (more sorting options as Hellioning mentioned) and some bugs need to be worked out (not being able to view posts on your profile), but this community definitely has the potential to surpass the forums and become the preferred board for League of Legends, it'll just take time.

Well, here's some of my feedback:

- The biggest issues I take with CB is that it's still nearly impossible for latecomers to join in on a discussion and actually be heard. Half the time *I* can't even find my post again.

- Anyone being able to bump a post to the top in the old forums could get obnoxious, but I actually think CB goes to far the other way: once a post is no longer right at the top pretty much the only way to generate new discussion is to completely remake the thread.

- I think it would help to smooth over the transition a lot if posts formatted for the old forums would display correctly here. I'm not sure how complicated that would be to implement here though.

- There's a lot of ways to abuse smurf accounts on here, and while I know Riot is aware of them, I feel like the issue has sort of been "shrugged off" thus far.

- I suggest you add an option for "Report thread: posted in wrong section" that flags a thread so the moderators can move it (if appropriate). I'm seeing lots of threads that clearly aren't where they belong.

pendragon, have you considered the fact that your new community beta forums are REDUNDANT?

those who prefer reddit style, will use reddit style.

furthermore, the filtering of comments will only every present the popular opinion.

So basically, the days of General Discussion are numbered.

I can see no advantages to the current design of the community beta for players. I feel it encourages conformity while it limits the depth and breadth of conversation and interaction that (I think) players really want in their forums. 

It's apparently more convenient for Riot though, which combined with the success of Reddit, is probably why it's going ahead (rather than GD).

So far I've only seen only very limited success with the conversations between Riot and players from these forums and certainly nothing that approaches the level of interaction that players have seen on GD (in the past).

It's a really disappointing decision to eventually close GD. I'm sure a lot of players are going to miss GD when it's gone.

To be very blunt, I have aired my complaints out so many times, I'm sure you could just take a look at the many threads on the subject and get a pretty good idea about what I do and don't like about the beta.

I still don't fully understand Riot's logic in creating this website. You already have two different communities on different websites. Emulating a different message board (and make no mistake, this is exactly what you are doing, despite your claims to the contrary) on your own website only makes your own site redundant. I mean, why come over here on your site when I get pretty much the same thing over on Reddit? If I can't use a layout I'm comfortable with (your traditional forums), I'm going to go where the people are, and the community here on the beta pales in comparison to the one on Reddit. Unless you take steps to shut down /r/leagueoflegends, this site will never get off the ground, and you'll drive off the people on GD. It's a lose-lose, which harms Riot and makes the Beta a colossal waste of time, effort, and money.

GD exists only because it's not Reddit. And you're taking that away.

I hate the Reddit style VISUAL style. It doesn't make logical sense to me, and to be completely honest, I will not use the new forums (potentially ever, even if you disable the old ones), because of it. Yes, my entire hatred of the new forums is visual style.

Do you mean the colors, or do you mean how comments are displayed in a tree instead of in a linear flat view? If it's the latter - have you tried switching your display mode to "flat" at the top of the comment section?

Thanks for the feedback!
Sorry for a late reply, but it's the Tree style.

The plan is and has always been to upgrade the community beta where it feels like a more natural place to post conversation as well as a better one. In fact I'd say as it is now it's incredibly better than anything on the old forums no matter how much nostalgia blindness some people suffer from. (Not referring to you, I'm more so talking about some less-than-cordial people).

The forums will ALWAYS be there in the current plans until this gets so good that everyone wants to come here and they can get rid of it. (Which will be never.)

I hate how this is styled after Reddit's format. Upvotes and Downvotes can serve to limit discussion by pushing controversial, but substantive topics down whereas unconstructive fluff (not to say that light hearted threads like champion appreciation ones should not exist) may get upvoted from time to time and take the place of truly positive threads.

I can barely follow thread conversations on Reddit and the Community Beta doesn't serve this any better because it is similar to Reddit.

That being said I do like how I have quick and easy access to the "subcommunities' and I can make a thread anywhere and have it posted on any subcommunity without having to enter it's site to make a post.

My suggestion is to keep the old forum's style of thread posting, conversation following and bumping but keep Reddit's accessibility to threads.

Pretty much what CaptainMarvelous said, there will be a switch eventually. But that probably won't be for at be for quite a while so there's really no reason to worry. 

I'll be the first to say the CB is still unfinished and there are things about it people won't like as it is now, but I highly advise you to at least give it an honest try you may be surprised at what you find.
